{{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Interleukin-8|IL-8 (Interleukin-8)]] * [[Interleukin-18|IL-18 (Interleukin-18)]]<ref name="Loffreda S 1998"/><ref name="Esposito K 2002"/> * [[Tumor necrosis factor-alpha|TNF-α (Tumor necrosis factor-alpha)]]<ref name="Loffreda S 1998"/><ref name="Esposito K 2002"/> * [[C-reactive protein|CRP (C-reactive protein)]]<ref name="Loffreda S 1998"/><ref name="Esposito K 2002"/> * [[Insulin]]<ref name="Loffreda S 1998"/><ref name="Esposito K 2002"/> * [[Blood sugar|Blood glucose]]<ref name="Loffreda S 1998"/><ref name="Esposito K 2002"/> * [[Leptin]]<ref name="Loffreda S 1998"/><ref name="Esposito K 2002"/> }} Low-grade chronic inflammation is characterized by a two- to threefold increase in the systemic concentrations of cytokines such as TNF-α, IL-6, and CRP.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Petersen |first=A. M. |last2=Pedersen |first2=B. K. |title=The anti-inflammatory effect of exercise |journal=J Appl Physiol |year=2005 |volume=98 |issue=4 |pages=1154–62 |doi=10.1152/japplphysiol.00164.2004 |pmid=15772055 }}</ref> Waist circumference correlates significantly with systemic inflammatory response.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Waist circumference as the predominant contributor to the micro-inflammatory response in the metabolic syndrome: a cross sectional study |journal=Journal of Inflammation |year=2010 |volume=7 |pages=35 |doi=10.1186/1476-9255-7-35 |pmc=2919526 |pmid=20659330 |author1=Rogowski |first1=O |last2=Shapira |first2=I |last3=Bassat |first3=O. K. |last4=Chundadze |first4=T |last5=Finn |first5=T |last6=Berliner |first6=S |last7=Steinvil |first7=A }}</ref> A predominant factor in this correlation is due to the autoimmune response triggered by adiposity, whereby immune cells may mistake fatty deposits for intruders. The body attacks fat like it does bacteria and fungi. When expanded fat cells leak or break open, macrophages mobilize to clean up and embed into the adipose tissue. Then macrophages release inflammatory chemicals, including TNF-α and IL-6. TNF's primary role is to regulate the immune cells and induce inflammation. White blood cells then assist by releasing more [[cytokine]]s. This link between adiposity and inflammation has been shown to produce 10–35% of IL-6 in a resting individual, and this production increases with increasing adiposity.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Subcutaneous adipose tissue releases interleukin-6, but not tumor necrosis factor-α, in vivo |journal=Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism |year=1997 |volume=82 |issue=12 |pages=4196–4200 |doi=10.1210/jc.82.12.4196 |pmid=9398739 |author1=Mohamed-Ali |first1=V |last2=Goodrick |first2=S |last3=Rawesh |first3=A |last4=Katz |first4=D. R. |last5=Miles |first5=J. M. |last6=Yudkin |first6=J. S. |last7=Klein |first7=S |last8=Coppack |first8=S. W. }}</ref>
Loss of [[white adipose tissue]] reduces levels of inflammation markers.<ref name=ParimisettyDorsemans2016 /> The association of systemic inflammation with [[insulin resistance]] and [[atherosclerosis]] is the subject of intense research.<ref name=Stitzinger>{{cite web |url=https://openaccess.leidenuniv.nl/dspace/bitstream/1887/9729/11/01.pdf |publisher= The digital repository of Leiden University |title= Lipids, inflammation and atherosclerosis |author=M Stitzinger |year=2007 |accessdate=2007-11-02 |format= pdf|website=}}</ref>
In the obese mouse models, inflammation and [[macrophage]]-specific genes are upregulated in white adipose tissue (WAT). There were also signs of dramatic increase in circulating [[insulin]] level, adipocyte lipolysis and formation of [[multinucleate]] [[giant cell]]s.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Chronic Inflammation in Fat Plays a Crucial Role in the Development of Obesity-Related Insulin Resistance |journal=J Clin Invest |year=2003 |volume=112 |issue=12 |pages=1821–30 |doi=10.1172/JCI19451 |pmid=14679177 |pmc=296998 |author1=Xu |first1=H |last2=Barnes |first2=G. T. |last3=Yang |first3=Q |last4=Tan |first4=G |last5=Yang |first5=D |last6=Chou |first6=C. J. |last7=Sole |first7=J |last8=Nichols |first8=A |last9=Ross |first9=J. S. |last10=Tartaglia |first10=L. A. |last11=Chen |first11=H }}</ref> The fat-derived protein called [[angiopoietin]]-like protein 2 (Angptl2) elevates in fat tissues. Higher than normal Angptl2 level in fat tissues develop inflammation as well as insulin and leptin resistance. Stored fat secretes leptin to signal satiety. Leptin resistance plays a role in the process where appetite overrules the message of satiety. Angptl2 then starts an inflammatory cascade causing blood vessels to remodel and attract macrophages. Angptl2 is an adipocyte-derived inflammatory mediator linking obesity to systemic insulin resistance.<ref name=KadomatsuTabata2011>{{cite journal|vauthors=Kadomatsu T, Tabata M, Oike Y|title=Angiopoietin-like proteins: emerging targets for treatment of obesity and related metabolic diseases|journal=FEBS J|volume=278|issue=4|pages=559–64|date=Feb 2011|pmid=21182596|url=https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/circj/73/12/73_CJ-09-0710/_pdf|doi=10.1111/j.1742-4658.2010.07979.x|type=Review}}</ref> It is possible that, as an inflammatory marker, [[Leptin#Clinical significance|leptin responds specifically]] to adipose-derived [[Proinflammatory cytokine|inflammatory cytokines]].
[[C-reactive protein]] (CRP) is generated at a higher level in obese people. It raises when there is inflammation throughout the body. Mild elevation in CRP increases risk of heart attacks, strokes, high blood pressure, asthma exacerbations,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Peters |first1=Michael C |last2=McGrath |first2=Kelly Wong |last3=Hawkins |first3=Gregory A |last4=Hastie |first4=Annette T |last5=Levy |first5=Bruce D |last6=Israel |first6=Elliot |last7=Phillips |first7=Brenda R |last8=Mauger |first8=David T |last9=Comhair |first9=Suzy A |last10=Erzurum |first10=Serpil C |last11=Johansson |first11=Mats W |last12=Jarjour |first12=Nizar N |last13=Coverstone |first13=Andrea M |last14=Castro |first14=Mario |last15=Holguin |first15=Fernando |last16=Wenzel |first16=Sally E |last17=Woodruff |first17=Prescott G |last18=Bleecker |first18=Eugene R |last19=Fahy |first19=John V |title=Plasma interleukin-6 concentrations, metabolic dysfunction, and asthma severity: a cross-sectional analysis of two cohorts |journal=The Lancet Respiratory Medicine |date=July 2016 |volume=4 |issue=7 |pages=574–584 |doi=10.1016/S2213-2600(16)30048-0|pmid=27283230 |pmc=5007068 }}</ref> muscle weakness and fragility.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.webmd.com/heart-disease/guide/heart-disease-c-reactive-protein-crp-testing|title=C-Reactive Protein (CRP) Testing for Heart Disease|work=WebMD|access-date=2017-06-04}}</ref>{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}}
=== Systemic inflammation and overeating === [[Hyperglycemia]] induces IL-6 production from endothelial cells and macrophages.<ref name="pmid16823477">{{cite journal|last=Shoelson|first=SE|author2=Lee, J |author3=Goldfine, AB |title=Inflammation and insulin resistance|journal=The Journal of Clinical Investigation|date=July 2006|volume=116|issue=7|pages=1793–801|doi=10.1172/JCI29069|pmid=16823477|pmc=1483173|type=Review}}</ref> Meals high in [[saturated fat]], as well as meals high in [[calories]] have been associated with increases in inflammatory markers.<ref name="pmid14624394">{{cite journal|last=Blackburn|first=Patricia|author2=Côté, Mélanie; Lamarche, Benoı̂t; Couillard, Charles; Pascot, Agnès; Tremblay, Angelo; Bergeron, Jean; Lemieux, Isabelle; Després, Jean-Pierre|title=Impact of postprandial variation in triglyceridemia on low-density lipoprotein particle size|journal=Metabolism|date=1 November 2003|volume=52|issue=11|pages=1379–86|doi=10.1016/S0026-0495(03)00315-9|pmid=14624394}}</ref><ref name="pmid19828712">{{cite journal|last=van Dijk|first=S. J|author2=Feskens, E. J.; Bos, M. B; Hoelen, D. W.; Heijligenberg, R.; Bromhaar, M. G.; de Groot, L. C.; de Vries, J. H.; Muller, M.; Afman, L. A|title=A saturated fatty acid-rich diet induces an obesity-linked proinflammatory gene expression profile in adipose tissue of subjects at risk of metabolic syndrome|journal=American Journal of Clinical Nutrition|date=14 October 2009|volume=90|issue=6|pages=1656–64|doi=10.3945/ajcn.2009.27792|pmid=19828712}}</ref> In addition, interstitial abdominal adiposity (also referred to as accumulated intra-abdominal fat) may be a factor in increasing systemic risk for multiple inflammatory diseases. Although the exact mechanisms are still being investigated, a review published in 2010 suggested that significant growth of adipose tissue in response to [[overeating]] can evoke a chronic inflammatory response.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Monteiro|first=Rosário|last2=Azevedo|first2=Isabel|date=2010|title=Chronic Inflammation in Obesity and the Metabolic Syndrome|journal=Mediators of Inflammation|volume=2010|doi=10.1155/2010/289645|issn=0962-9351|pmc=2913796|pmid=20706689|pages=1–10}}</ref>
== Outcomes == [[File:Scar (xndr).jpg|250px|thumb|right|Scars present on the skin, evidence of fibrosis and healing of a wound]] The outcome in a particular circumstance will be determined by the tissue in which the injury has occurred and the injurious agent that is causing it. Here are the possible outcomes to inflammation:<ref name="robspath" />
# '''Resolution'''<br />The complete restoration of the inflamed tissue back to a normal status. Inflammatory measures such as vasodilation, chemical production, and leukocyte infiltration cease, and damaged [[parenchyma]]l cells regenerate. In situations where limited or short-lived inflammation has occurred this is usually the outcome. # '''[[Fibrosis]]'''<br />Large amounts of tissue destruction, or damage in tissues unable to regenerate, cannot be regenerated completely by the body. Fibrous [[scarring]] occurs in these areas of damage, forming a scar composed primarily of [[collagen]]. The scar will not contain any specialized structures, such as [[parenchyma]]l cells, hence functional impairment may occur. # '''Abscess formation'''<br />A cavity is formed containing pus, an opaque liquid containing dead white blood cells and bacteria with general debris from destroyed cells. # '''Chronic inflammation'''<br />In acute inflammation, if the injurious agent persists then chronic inflammation will ensue. This process, marked by inflammation lasting many days, months or even years, may lead to the formation of a [[chronic wound]]. Chronic inflammation is characterised by the dominating presence of macrophages in the injured tissue. These cells are powerful defensive agents of the body, but the [[toxin]]s they release (including [[reactive oxygen species]]) are injurious to the organism's own tissues as well as invading agents. As a consequence, chronic inflammation is almost always accompanied by tissue destruction.
== Examples == Inflammation is usually indicated by adding the suffix "[[wikt:-itis|itis]]", as shown below. However, some conditions such as [[asthma]] and [[pneumonia]] do not follow this convention. More examples are available at [[list of types of inflammation]].
<gallery> File:Acute_Appendicitis.jpg|Acute [[appendicitis]] File:Dermatitis.jpg|Acute [[dermatitis]] File:Streptococcus pneumoniae meningitis, gross pathology 33 lores.jpg|Acute infective [[meningitis]] File:Tonsillitis.jpg|Acute [[tonsillitis]] </gallery>
== Diet and inflammation == The Dietary Inflammatory Index (DII) is a score (number) that describes the potential of diet to modulate systemic inflammation within the body. As stated chronic inflammation is linked to most chronic diseases including arthritis, many types of cancer, cardiovascular diseases, inflammatory bowel diseases, and diabetes.
== Exercise and inflammation ==
===Exercise-induced acute inflammation===
Acute inflammation of the [[muscle cells]], as understood in exercise physiology,<ref>{{cite book|last=Wilmore|first=Jack|title=Physiology of Sport and Exercise|year=2008|publisher=Human Kinetics|location=Champaign, IL|isbn=978-0-7360-5583-3|pages=26–36, 98–120, 186–250, 213–218}}</ref> can result after [[Muscle contraction|induced]] [[Eccentric contraction|eccentric]] and [[Concentric contraction|concentric]] muscle training. Participation in eccentric training and conditioning, including resistance training and activities that emphasize eccentric lengthening of the [[muscle]] including downhill running on a moderate to high incline can result in considerable soreness within 24 to 48 hours, even though [[blood lactate]] levels, previously thought to cause muscle soreness, were much higher with level running. This [[delayed onset muscle soreness]] (DOMS) results from structural damage to the contractile filaments and [[Muscle cells|z-disks]], which has been noted especially in [[marathon runner]]s whose muscle fibers revealed [[Myopathy|remarkable damage]] to the muscle fibers after both training and marathon competition <ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.humankinetics.com/excerpts/excerpts/recent-research-provides-insight-into-muscle-soreness|title=Physiology of Sport and Exercise 5E: Delayed-Onset Muscle Soreness|work=human-kinetics|access-date=2017-06-04|language=En}}</ref>{{Citation needed|date=October 2013}}. The onset and timing of this gradient damage to the muscle parallels the degree of muscle soreness experienced by the runners.
Z-disks are the point of contact for the contractile proteins. They provide structural support for transmission of force when muscle fibers are activated to shorten. However, in marathon runners and those who subscribe to the overload principle to enhance their muscles, show moderate Z-disk streaming and major disruption of thick and thin filaments in parallel groups of sarcomeres as a result of the force of eccentric actions or stretching of tightened muscle fibers.
This disruption of muscle fibers triggers white blood cells to increase following induced muscle soreness, leading to the inflammatory response observation from induced muscle soreness. Elevations in plasma enzymes, myoglobinemia, and abnormal muscle histology and ultrastructure are concluded to be associated with inflammatory response. High tension in the contractile-elastic system of muscle results in structural damage to the muscle fiber and plasmalemma and its epimysium, perimysium, and/or endomysium. The mysium damage disrupts calcium homeostasis in injured fibers and fiber bundles, resulting in necrosis that peaks about 48 hours after exercise. The products of macrophage activity and intracellular contents (such as histamines, kinins, and K<sup>+</sup>) accumulate outside cells. These substances then stimulate free nerve endings in the muscle; a process that appears accentuated by eccentric exercise, in which large forces are distributed over a relatively small cross-sectional area of the muscle<ref name=":1" /> {{Citation needed|date=October 2013}}.
===Post-inflammatory muscle growth and repair===
There is a known relationship between inflammation and muscle growth.<ref name="pmid15613683">{{cite journal|last=Toth|first=M. J.|title=Age-related differences in skeletal muscle protein synthesis: relation to markers of immune activation|journal=AJP: Endocrinology and Metabolism|date=29 December 2004|volume=288|issue=5|pages=E883–E891|doi=10.1152/ajpendo.00353.2004|pmid=15613683|first2=DE|last3=Tracy|first3=RP|last4=Previs|first4=MJ|last2=Matthews}}</ref> For instance, high doses of anti-inflammatory medicines (e.g., [[NSAID]]s) are able to blunt muscle growth.<ref name="pmid19713429">{{cite journal|last=Mikkelsen|first=U. R.|author2=Langberg, H. |author3=Helmark, I. C. |author4=Skovgaard, D. |author5=Andersen, L. L. |author6=Kjaer, M. |author7= Mackey, A. L. |title=Local NSAID infusion inhibits satellite cell proliferation in human skeletal muscle after eccentric exercise|journal=Journal of Applied Physiology|date=27 August 2009|volume=107|issue=5|pages=1600–11|doi=10.1152/japplphysiol.00707.2009|pmid=19713429|pmc=3774508}}</ref><ref name="pmid11832356">{{cite journal|last=Trappe|first=TA|author2=White, F |author3=Lambert, CP |author4=Cesar, D |author5=Hellerstein, M |author6= Evans, WJ |title=Effect of ibuprofen and acetaminophen on postexercise muscle protein synthesis|journal=American Journal of Physiology. Endocrinology and Metabolism|date=March 2002|volume=282|issue=3|pages=E551–6|pmid=11832356|doi=10.1152/ajpendo.00352.2001}}</ref>{{Original research inline|date=October 2017}} Cold therapy has been shown to negatively affect muscle growth as well. Reducing inflammation results in decreased macrophage activity and lower levels of IGF-1<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Influence of icing on muscle regeneration after crush injury to skeletal muscles in rats|journal = Journal of Applied Physiology|date = 2011-02-01|pmid = 21164157|pages = 382–8|volume = 110|issue = 2|doi = 10.1152/japplphysiol.01187.2010|first = Ryo|last = Takagi|first2 = Naoto|last2 = Fujita|first3 = Takamitsu|last3 = Arakawa|first4 = Shigeo|last4 = Kawada|first5 = Naokata|last5 = Ishii|first6 = Akinori|last6 = Miki}}</ref> Acute effects of cold therapy on training adaptations show reduced satellite cell proliferation.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Local NSAID infusion inhibits satellite cell proliferation in human skeletal muscle after eccentric exercise|url = http://jap.physiology.org/content/107/5/1600|journal = Journal of Applied Physiology|date = 2009-11-01|pmc = 3774508|pmid = 19713429|pages = 1600–11|volume = 107|issue = 5|doi = 10.1152/japplphysiol.00707.2009|first = U. R.|last = Mikkelsen|first2 = H.|last2 = Langberg|first3 = I. C.|last3 = Helmark|first4 = D.|last4 = Skovgaard|first5 = L. L.|last5 = Andersen|first6 = M.|last6 = Kjær|first7 = A. L.|last7 = Mackey}}</ref> Long term effects include less muscular hypertrophy and an altered cell structure of muscle fibers.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Post-exercise cold water immersion attenuates acute anabolic signalling and long-term adaptations in muscle to strength training|journal = The Journal of Physiology|date = 2015-09-15|pmc = 4594298|pmid = 26174323|pages = 4285–4301|volume = 593|issue = 18|doi = 10.1113/JP270570|first = Llion A.|last = Roberts|first2 = Truls|last2 = Raastad|first3 = James F.|last3 = Markworth|first4 = Vandre C.|last4 = Figueiredo|first5 = Ingrid M.|last5 = Egner|first6 = Anthony|last6 = Shield|first7 = David|last7 = Cameron-Smith|first8 = Jeff S.|last8 = Coombes|first9 = Jonathan M.|last9 = Peake}}</ref>
It has been further theorized that the acute localized inflammatory responses to muscular contraction during exercise, as described above, are a necessary precursor to muscle growth.<ref name="pmid21030670">{{cite journal|last=Marimuthu|first=K.|author2=Murton, A. J. |author3=Greenhaff, P. L. |title=Mechanisms regulating muscle mass during disuse atrophy and rehabilitation in humans|journal=Journal of Applied Physiology|date=28 October 2010|volume=110|issue=2|pages=555–560|doi=10.1152/japplphysiol.00962.2010|pmid=21030670}}</ref> As a response to muscular contractions, the acute inflammatory response initiates the breakdown and removal of damaged muscle tissue.<ref name="pmid9543358">{{cite journal|last=Cannon|first=Joseph G.|author2=St. Pierre, Barbara A.|journal=Molecular and Cellular Biochemistry|date=1 January 1998|volume=179|issue=1/2|pages=159–168|doi=10.1023/A:1006828425418|pmid=9543358|title=Cytokines in exertion-induced skeletal muscle injury}}</ref> Muscles can synthesize cytokines in response to contractions,<ref name="pmid15549417">{{cite journal|last=Lang|first=Charles H.|author2=Hong-Brown, Ly |author3=Frost, Robert A. |title=Cytokine inhibition of JAK-STAT signaling: a new mechanism of growth hormone resistance|journal=Pediatric Nephrology|date=10 November 2004|volume=20|issue=3|pages=306–312|doi=10.1007/s00467-004-1607-9|pmid=15549417}}</ref><ref name="pmid10953894">{{cite journal|last=Pedersen|first=BK|author2=Toft, AD|title=Effects of exercise on lymphocytes and cytokines|journal=British Journal of Sports Medicine|date=August 2000|volume=34|issue=4|pages=246–51|doi=10.1136/bjsm.34.4.246|pmid=10953894|pmc=1724218}}</ref><ref name="Bruunsgaard">{{cite journal|last=Bruunsgaard|first=H|author2=Galbo, H |author3=Halkjaer-Kristensen, J |author4=Johansen, TL |author5=MacLean, DA |author6= Pedersen, BK |title=Exercise-induced increase in serum interleukin-6 in humans is related to muscle damage|journal=The Journal of Physiology|date=Mar 15, 1997|volume=499|pages=833–41|pmid=9130176|pmc=1159298|issue=Pt 3 |doi=10.1113/jphysiol.1997.sp021972}}</ref> such that the cytokines [[IL1B|interleukin-1 beta (IL-1β)]], TNF-α, and IL-6 are expressed in skeletal muscle up to 5 days after exercise.<ref name="pmid9543358" />
In particular, the increase in levels of IL-6 ([[interleukin 6]]), a [[myokine]], can reach up to one hundred times that of resting levels.<ref name="Bruunsgaard" /> Depending on volume, intensity, and other training factors, the IL-6 increase associated with training initiates about 4 hours after resistance training and remains elevated for up to 24 hours.<ref name="McKay">{{cite journal|last=McKay|first=Bryon R.|author2=De Lisio, Michael; Johnston, Adam P. W.; O'Reilly, Ciara E.; Phillips, Stuart M.; Tarnopolsky, Mark A.; Parise, Gianni; Hotchin, Neil|title=Association of Interleukin-6 Signalling with the Muscle Stem Cell Response Following Muscle-Lengthening Contractions in Humans|journal=PLoS ONE|date=23 June 2009|volume=4|issue=6|pages=e6027|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0006027|pmid=19554087|pmc=2696599|editor1-last=Hotchin|editor1-first=Neil|bibcode=2009PLoSO...4.6027M|last3=Johnston|first3=Adam P. W.|last4=O'Reilly|first4=Ciara E.|last5=Phillips|first5=Stuart M.|last6=Tarnopolsky|first6=Mark A.|last7=Parise|first7=Gianni}}</ref><ref name="pmid 11320633">{{cite journal|last=MacIntyre|first=Donna L.|author2=Sorichter, Stephan |author3=Mair, Johannes |author4=McKenzie, Donald C. |author5= Berg, Aloys |title=Markers of inflammation and myofibrillar proteins following eccentric exercise in humans|journal=European Journal of Applied Physiology|date=11 March 2001|volume=84|issue=3|pages=180–6|doi=10.1007/s004210170002|pmid=11320633}}</ref><ref name="Louis 2007"/>
These acute increases in cytokines, as a response to muscle contractions, help initiate the process of muscle repair and growth by activating [[satellite cell]]s within the inflamed muscle. Satellite cells are crucial for skeletal muscle adaptation to exercise.<ref name="Serrano">{{cite journal|last=Serrano|first=AL|author2=Baeza-Raja, B |author3=Perdiguero, E |author4=Jardí, M |author5= Muñoz-Cánoves, P |title=Interleukin-6 is an essential regulator of satellite cell-mediated skeletal muscle hypertrophy.|journal=Cell Metabolism|date=Jan 2008|volume=7|issue=1|pages=33–44|doi=10.1016/j.cmet.2007.11.011|pmid=18177723}}</ref> They contribute to hypertrophy by providing new myonuclei and repair damaged segments of mature myofibers for successful regeneration following injury- or exercise-induced muscle damage;<ref name="pmid11967271">{{cite journal|last=Grounds|first=MD|author2=White, JD |author3=Rosenthal, N |author4= Bogoyevitch, MA |title=The role of stem cells in skeletal and cardiac muscle repair.|journal=Journal of Histochemistry and Cytochemistry|date=May 2002|volume=50|issue=5|pages=589–610|doi=10.1177/002215540205000501|pmid=11967271}}</ref><ref name="pmid11457764">{{cite journal|last=Hawke|first=TJ|author2=Garry, DJ|title=Myogenic satellite cells: physiology to molecular biology.|journal=Journal of Applied Physiology|date=Aug 2001|volume=91|issue=2|pages=534–51|pmid=11457764|doi=10.1152/jappl.2001.91.2.534}}</ref><ref name="pmid15821426">{{cite journal|last=Hawke|first=TJ|title=Muscle stem cells and exercise training.|journal=Exercise and Sport Sciences Reviews|date=Apr 2005|volume=33|issue=2|pages=63–8|doi=10.1097/00003677-200504000-00002|pmid=15821426}}</ref> high-level [[powerlifting|powerlifters]] can have up to 100% more satellite cells than untrained controls.<ref name="pmid10094415">{{cite journal|last=Kadi|first=F|author2=Eriksson, A |author3=Holmner, S |author4=Butler-Browne, GS |author5= Thornell, LE |title=Cellular adaptation of the trapezius muscle in strength-trained athletes.|journal=Histochemistry and Cell Biology|date=Mar 1999|volume=111|issue=3|pages=189–95|doi=10.1007/s004180050348|pmid=10094415}}</ref><ref name="pmid16059740">{{cite journal|last=Eriksson|first=A|author2=Kadi, F |author3=Malm, C |author4= Thornell, LE |title=Skeletal muscle morphology in power-lifters with and without anabolic steroids.|journal=Histochemistry and Cell Biology|date=Aug 2005|volume=124|issue=2|pages=167–75|doi=10.1007/s00418-005-0029-5|pmid=16059740}}</ref>
A rapid and transient localization of the IL-6 receptor and increased IL-6 expression occurs in satellite cells following contractions.<ref name="McKay" /> IL-6 has been shown to mediate hypertrophic muscle growth both ''[[in vitro]]'' and ''[[in vivo]]''.<ref name="Serrano" /> Unaccustomed exercise can increase IL-6 by up to sixfold at 5 hours post-exercise and threefold 8 days after exercise.<ref name="pmid20738823">{{cite journal|last=Mikkelsen|first=UR|author2=Schjerling, P |author3=Helmark, IC |author4=Reitelseder, S |author5=Holm, L |author6=Skovgaard, D |author7=Langberg, H |author8=Kjaer, M |author9= Heinemeier, KM |title=Local NSAID infusion does not affect protein synthesis and gene expression in human muscle after eccentric exercise|journal=Scandinavian Journal of Medicine & Science in Sports|date=Oct 2011|volume=21|issue=5|pages=630–44|doi=10.1111/j.1600-0838.2010.01170.x|pmid=20738823}}</ref> Also telling is the fact that NSAIDs can decrease satellite cell response to exercise,<ref name="pmid19713429" /> thereby reducing exercise-induced protein synthesis.<ref name="pmid11832356" />
The increase in [[cytokines]] ([[myokine]]s) after resistance exercise coincides with the decrease in levels of [[myostatin]], a protein that inhibits muscle differentiation and growth.<ref name="Louis 2007">{{cite journal|last=Louis|first=E|author2=Raue, U |author3=Yang, Y |author4=Jemiolo, B |author5= Trappe, S |title=Time course of proteolytic, cytokine, and myostatin gene expression after acute exercise in human skeletal muscle.|journal=Journal of Applied Physiology|date=Nov 2007|volume=103|issue=5|pages=1744–51|doi=10.1152/japplphysiol.00679.2007|pmid=17823296}}</ref> The cytokine response to resistance exercise and moderate-intensity running occur differently, with the latter causing a more prolonged response, especially at the 12–24 hour mark.<ref name="Louis 2007"/>
Developing research has demonstrated that many of the benefits of exercise are mediated through the role of skeletal muscle as an endocrine organ. That is, contracting muscles release multiple substances known as [[myokine]]s, including but not limited to those cited in the above description, which promote the growth of new tissue, tissue repair, and various anti-inflammatory functions, which in turn reduce the risk of developing various inflammatory diseases. The new view that muscle is an endocrine organ is transforming our understanding of exercise physiology and with it, of the role of inflammation in adaptation to stress.<ref name="inflammation-metabolism.dk">{{cite book|last=Pedersen|first=BK|date=Jul 2013|title=Muscle as a secretory organ|journal=Comprehensive Physiology|volume=3|issue=3|pages=1337–62|doi=10.1002/cphy.c120033|isbn=9780470650714|pmid=23897689}}</ref>
=== Chronic inflammation and muscle loss ===
Both chronic and extreme inflammation are associated with disruptions of anabolic signals initiating muscle growth. Chronic inflammation has been implicated as part of the cause of the [[sarcopenia|muscle loss that occurs with aging]].<ref name="pmid15613683" /><ref name="pmid11983728">{{cite journal|last=Visser|first=M|author2=Pahor, M |author3=Taaffe, DR |author4=Goodpaster, BH |author5=Simonsick, EM |author6=Newman, AB |author7=Nevitt, M |author8= Harris, TB |title=Relationship of interleukin-6 and tumor necrosis factor-alpha with muscle mass and muscle strength in elderly men and women: the Health ABC Study.|journal=The Journals of Gerontology. Series A, Biological Sciences and Medical Sciences|date=May 2002|volume=57|issue=5|pages=M326–32|doi=10.1093/gerona/57.5.M326|pmid=11983728}}</ref> Increased protein levels of myostatin have been described in patients with diseases characterized by chronic low-grade inflammation.<ref name="pmid11410916">{{cite journal|last=Reardon|first=KA|author2=Davis, J |author3=Kapsa, RM |author4=Choong, P |author5= Byrne, E |title=Myostatin, insulin-like growth factor-1, and leukemia inhibitory factor mRNAs are upregulated in chronic human disuse muscle atrophy.|journal=Muscle & Nerve|date=Jul 2001|volume=24|issue=7|pages=893–9|doi=10.1002/mus.1086|pmid=11410916}}</ref> Increased levels of TNF-α can suppress the AKT/mTOR pathway, a crucial pathway for regulating skeletal muscle hypertrophy,<ref>Shih, Michael. "Skeletal Muscle Hypertrophy Is Regulated via AKT/mTOR Pathway." BioCarta. Web. 21 March 2011. {{cite web|url=http://www.biocarta.com/pathfiles/m_igf1mtorpathway.asp |title=Blogger |accessdate=2011-03-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100914112924/http://www.biocarta.com/pathfiles/m_igf1mtorpathway.asp |archivedate=14 September 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref> thereby increasing muscle [[catabolism]].<ref name="pmid17161226">{{cite journal|last=Lang|first=CH|author2=Frost, RA|title=Sepsis-induced suppression of skeletal muscle translation initiation mediated by tumor necrosis factor alpha.|journal=Metabolism: Clinical and Experimental|date=Jan 2007|volume=56|issue=1|pages=49–57|doi=10.1016/j.metabol.2006.08.025|pmid=17161226}}</ref><ref name="pmid8264567">{{cite journal|last=García-Martínez|first=C|author2=López-Soriano, FJ |author3=Argilés, JM |title=Acute treatment with tumour necrosis factor-alpha induces changes in protein metabolism in rat skeletal muscle.|journal=Molecular and Cellular Biochemistry|date=Aug 11, 1993|volume=125|issue=1|pages=11–8|doi=10.1007/BF00926829|pmid=8264567}}</ref><ref name="pmid15710765">{{cite journal|last=Janssen|first=SP|author2=Gayan-Ramirez, G; Van den Bergh, A; Herijgers, P; Maes, K; Verbeken, E; Decramer, M|title=Interleukin-6 causes myocardial failure and skeletal muscle atrophy in rats|journal=Circulation|date=Mar 1, 2005|volume=111|issue=8|pages=996–1005|doi=10.1161/01.CIR.0000156469.96135.0D|pmid=15710765}}</ref> Cytokines may [[receptor antagonist|antagonize]] the [[anabolic]] effects of [[Insulin-like growth factor 1|insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1)]].<ref name="Lang">{{cite journal|last=Lang|first=CH|author2=Frost, RA |author3=Vary, TC |title=Regulation of muscle protein synthesis during sepsis and inflammation.|journal=American Journal of Physiology. Endocrinology and Metabolism|date=Aug 2007|volume=293|issue=2|pages=E453–9|doi=10.1152/ajpendo.00204.2007|pmid=17505052}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Jurasinski|first=CV|author2=Vary, TC|title=Insulin-like growth factor I accelerates protein synthesis in skeletal muscle during sepsis.|journal=The American Journal of Physiology|date=Nov 1995|volume=269|issue=5 Pt 1|pages=E977–81|pmid=7491951|doi=10.1152/ajpendo.1995.269.5.E977}}</ref> In the case of [[sepsis]], an extreme whole body inflammatory state, the synthesis of both [[myofibrillar hypertrophy|myofibrillar]] and [[sarcoplasmic hypertrophy|sarcoplasmic]] proteins are inhibited, with the inhibition taking place preferentially in [[skeletal muscle|fast-twitch muscle fibers]].<ref name="Lang" /><ref name="pmid1371643">{{cite journal|last=Vary|first=TC|author2=Kimball, SR|title=Regulation of hepatic protein synthesis in chronic inflammation and sepsis.|journal=The American Journal of Physiology|date=Feb 1992|volume=262|issue=2 Pt 1|pages=C445–52|pmid=1371643|doi=10.1152/ajpcell.1992.262.2.C445}}</ref> Sepsis is also able to prevent [[leucine]] from stimulating muscle protein synthesis.<ref name="pmid15549417" /> In animal models, when inflammation is created, [[mTOR]] loses its ability to be stimulated by muscle growth.<ref name="pmid20388826">{{cite journal|last=Lang|first=CH|author2=Frost, RA |author3=Bronson, SK |author4=Lynch, CJ |author5= Vary, TC |title=Skeletal muscle protein balance in mTOR heterozygous mice in response to inflammation and leucine.|journal=American Journal of Physiology. Endocrinology and Metabolism|date=Jun 2010|volume=298|issue=6|pages=E1283–94|doi=10.1152/ajpendo.00676.2009|pmid=20388826|pmc=2886531}}</ref>
===Exercise as a treatment for inflammation===
Regular physical activity is reported to decrease markers of inflammation,<ref name="pmid10328073">{{cite journal|author1=Smith JK|author2=Dykes R |author3=Douglas JE |author4=Krishnaswamy G |author5= Berk S |title=Long-term exercise and atherogenic activity of blood mononuclear cells in persons at risk of developing ischemic heart disease|journal=[[JAMA: the Journal of the American Medical Association]]|date=May 12, 1999|volume=281|issue=18|pages=1722–7|doi=10.1001/jama.281.18.1722|pmid=10328073}}</ref><ref name="pmid16282566">{{cite journal|last=McFarlin|first=BK|author2=Flynn, MG |author3=Phillips, MD |author4=Stewart, LK |author5= Timmerman, KL |title=Chronic resistance exercise training improves natural killer cell activity in older women|journal=The Journals of Gerontology. Series A, Biological Sciences and Medical Sciences|date=October 2005|volume=60|issue=10|pages=1315–8|doi=10.1093/gerona/60.10.1315|pmid=16282566}} {{medrs|date=April 2016}}</ref><ref name="pmid15963685">{{cite journal |author=Stewart LK|author2=Flynn MG |author3=Campbell WW |author4=Craig BA |author5=Robinson JP |author6=McFarlin, BK |author7=Timmerman KL |author8=Coen PM |author9=Felker J |author10= Talbert E |title=Influence of exercise training and age on CD14+ cell-surface expression of toll-like receptor 2 and 4 |journal=Brain, Behavior, and Immunity|date=September 2005|volume=19|issue=5|pages=389–97|doi=10.1016/j.bbi.2005.04.003 |pmid=15963685 }} {{medrs|date=April 2016}}</ref> although the correlation is imperfect and seems to reveal differing results contingent upon training intensity. For instance, while baseline measurements of circulating inflammatory markers do not seem to differ greatly between healthy trained and untrained adults,<ref name="Gleeson 2006">{{cite journal|last=Gleeson|first=M|title=Immune system adaptation in elite athletes.|journal=Current Opinion in Clinical Nutrition and Metabolic Care|date=Nov 2006|volume=9|issue=6|pages=659–65|doi=10.1097/01.mco.0000247476.02650.18|pmid=17053416}}</ref><ref name="pmid10893431">{{cite journal|last=Pedersen|first=BK|author2=Hoffman-Goetz, L|title=Exercise and the immune system: regulation, integration, and adaptation.|journal=Physiological Reviews|date=Jul 2000|volume=80|issue=3|pages=1055–81|pmid=10893431|doi=10.1152/physrev.2000.80.3.1055}}</ref> long-term training may help reduce chronic low-grade inflammation.<ref name="Ploeger 2009">{{cite journal|title=The effects of acute and chronic exercise on inflammatory markers in children and adults with a chronic inflammatory disease: a systematic review|journal=Exercise Immunology Review|year=2009|volume=15|pages=6–41|pmid=19957870|author1=Ploeger|first1=H. E.|last2=Takken|first2=T|last3=De Greef|first3=M. H.|last4=Timmons|first4=B. W.}}</ref> On the other hand, levels of the anti-inflammatory [[myokine]] IL-6 ([[interleukin 6]]) remained elevated longer into the recovery period following an acute bout of exercise in patients with inflammatory diseases, relative to the recovery of healthy controls.<ref name="Ploeger 2009"/> It may well be that low-intensity training can reduce resting pro-inflammatory markers (CRP, IL-6), while moderate-intensity training has milder and less-established anti-inflammatory benefits.<ref name="Gleeson 2006"/><ref name="pmid19016938">{{cite journal|author1=Nicklas BJ |author2=Hsu FC |author3=Brinkley TJ |author4=Church T |author5=Goodpaster BH |author6=Kritchevsky SB |author7= Pahor, M |title=Exercise training and plasma C-reactive protein and interleukin-6 in elderly people.|journal=Journal of the American Geriatrics Society|date=November 2008|volume=56|issue=11|pages=2045–52|doi=10.1111/j.1532-5415.2008.01994.x|pmid=19016938|pmc=2683336}} {{medrs|date=April 2016}}</ref><ref name="pmid18664531">{{cite journal|author1=Timmerman KL|author2=Flynn MG |author3=Coen PM |author4=Markofski MM |author5= Pence BD |title=Exercise training-induced lowering of inflammatory (CD14+CD16+) monocytes: a role in the anti-inflammatory influence of exercise?|journal=Journal of Leukocyte Biology|date=Nov 2008|volume=84|issue=5|pages=1271–8|pmid=18664531|doi=10.1189/jlb.0408244}} {{medrs|date=April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Mackinnon LT |title=Chronic exercise training effects on immune function |journal=Med Sci Sports Exerc |date=July 2000 |volume=32 |issue=7 Suppl |pages=S369–76 |pmid=10910293 }} {{medrs|date=April 2016}}</ref> There is a strong relationship between exhaustive exercise and chronic low-grade inflammation.<ref name="pmid12569227">{{cite journal|author1=Suzuki Katsuhiko|author2=Nakaji Shigeyuki |author3=Yamada Mutsuo |author4=Liu Qiang |author5=Kurakake Shigeyoshi |author6=Okamura Noriyoshi |author7=Kumae Takashi |author8=Umeda Takashi |author9= Sugawara Kazuo |title=Impact of a competitive marathon race on systemic cytokine and neutrophil responses |journal=Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise|date=February 2003|volume=35|issue=2|pages=348–55 |doi=10.1249/01.MSS.0000048861.57899.04 |pmid=12569227}} {{medrs|date=April 2016}}</ref> Marathon running may enhance IL-6 levels as much as 100 times over normal and increases total leuckocyte count and neturophil mobilization.<ref name="pmid12569227" />
Regarding the above, IL-6 had previously been classified as a proinflammatory cytokine. Therefore, it was first thought that the exercise-induced IL-6 response was related to muscle damage.<ref name="pmid9130176">{{cite journal | author = Bruunsgaard H, Galbo H, Halkjaer-Kristensen J, Johansen TL, MacLean DA, Pedersen BK | title = Exercise-induced increase in serum interleukin-6 in humans is related to muscle damage | journal = Journal of Physiology | volume = 499 | issue = Pt 3| pages = 833–41 |date=March 1997 | pmid = 9130176 | pmc = 1159298 | doi = 10.1113/jphysiol.1997.sp021972| last2 = Galbo | last3 = Halkjaer-Kristensen | last4 = Johansen | last5 = MacLean | last6 = Pedersen }}</ref> However, it has become evident that eccentric exercise is not associated with a larger increase in plasma IL-6 than exercise involving concentric “nondamaging” muscle contractions. This finding clearly demonstrates that muscle damage is not required to provoke an increase in plasma IL-6 during exercise. As a matter of fact, eccentric exercise may result in a delayed peak and a much slower decrease of plasma IL-6 during recovery.<ref name="pmid23897689">{{cite book | author = Pedersen BK | title = Muscle as a secretory organ | journal = Compr Physiol | volume = 3 | issue = 3 | pages = 1337–62 |date=July 2013 | pmid = 23897689 | doi = 10.1002/cphy.c120033 | isbn = 9780470650714 }}</ref>
Recent work has shown that both upstream and downstream signalling pathways for IL-6 differ markedly between myocytes and macrophages. It appears that unlike IL-6 signalling in macrophages, which is dependent upon activation of the NFκB signalling pathway, intramuscular IL-6 expression is regulated by a network of signalling cascades, including the Ca2+/NFAT and glycogen/p38 MAPK pathways. Thus, when IL-6 is signalling in monocytes or macrophages, it creates a pro-inflammatory response, whereas IL-6 activation and signalling in muscle is totally independent of a preceding TNF-response or NFκB activation, and is anti-inflammatory.<ref name="TheRole">{{cite journal|author1=Brandt C |author2=Pedersen BK|title=The role of exercise-induced myokines in muscle homeostasis and the defense against chronic diseases |journal=Journal of Biomedicine & Biotechnology|year=2010|volume=2010|pages=1–6|pmid=20224659|doi=10.1155/2010/520258|pmc=2836182}}</ref>
Several studies show that markers of inflammation are reduced following longer-term behavioural changes involving both reduced energy intake and a regular program of increased physical activity, and that, in particular, IL-6 was miscast as an inflammatory marker. For example, the anti-inflammatory effects of IL-6 have been demonstrated by IL-6 stimulating the production of the classical anti-inflammatory cytokines IL-1ra and IL-10.<ref name="TheRole" /> As such, individuals pursuing exercise as a means to treat the causal factors underlying chronic inflammation are pursuing a course of action strongly supported by current research, as an inactive lifestyle is strongly associated with the development and progression of multiple inflammatory diseases. Note that cautions regarding over-exertion may apply in certain cases, as discussed above, though this concern rarely applies to the general population.
===Signal-to-noise theory===
Given that localized acute inflammation is a necessary component for muscle growth, and that chronic low-grade inflammation is associated with a disruption of anabolic signals initiating muscle growth, it has been theorized that a [[signal-to-noise]] model may best describe the relationship between inflammation and muscle growth.<ref>Pilon, Brad. "[https://web.archive.org/web/20160509091232/http://www.inflammationtheory.com/ Inflammation Affects Your Ability to Build Muscle]" ''Inflammation Theory''</ref> By keeping the "noise" of chronic inflammation to a minimum, the localized acute inflammatory response signals a stronger anabolic response than could be achieved with higher levels of chronic inflammation.
== See also == {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Anaphylatoxin]] * [[Anti-inflammatory|Anti-inflammatories]] * [[Essential fatty acid interactions]] * [[Healing]] * [[Inflammatory reflex]] * [[Interleukin]] * [[Lipoxin]] * [[Neurogenic inflammation]] * [[Substance P]] }}
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== External links == {{commons category|Inflammation}} * {{MeshName|Inflammation}}
{{Inflammation}} {{Immune system}} {{Pathology}}
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox company <!-- empty fields have been removed - consult template documentation to recover fields as needed --> | name = Intarcia Therapeutics, Inc. | logo = Intarcia Therapeutics logo.png | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | foundation = Hayward, California, United States ({{Start date|1995}}) | location_city = [[Boston, MA]] | location_country = United States | key_people = {{ubl|Kurt C. Graves (Chairman, President and CEO)}} | industry = [[pharmaceutical industry]] | products = Medici Drug Delivery System | homepage = {{URL|http://intarcia.com/}} | footnotes = }} '''Intarcia Therapeutics''' is an American [[biopharmaceutical]] company based in [[Boston, MA]] and incorporated under the laws of [[Delaware]].<ref name=bloombergsnapshot/><ref name=sec/> It was founded in 1995 under the name "BioMedicines" and changed to its present name in 2004.<ref name=bloombergsnapshot/> In 2013, Intarcia relocated its headquarters to Boston, keeping its manufacturing facility in Hayward, CA. In addition to Boston and Hayward, Intarcia also has a location in Research Triangle Park, North Carolina, where it discovers and develops peptides for its drug delivery system.<ref name="fiercebiotech.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.fiercebiotech.com/r-d/investors-pump-200m-into-intarcia-s-phiii-for-once-yearly-diabetes-therapy|title=Investors pump $200M into Intarcia's PhIII for once-yearly diabetes therapy|website=www.fiercebiotech.com}}</ref>
In 2005, the executive leadership of Intarcia was largely vested in two people, Karling Leung and James Ahlers, President/CEO/Director and Vice President/CFO/Finance & Operations Officer, respectively.<ref name=S12005/> By 2012, Kurt Graves had replaced Karling Leung as President and CEO.<ref name=leuty/> Kurt Graves has been with Intarcia since August 2010, first serving as Executive Chairman before becoming President and CEO in April 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/markets/stocks|title=Stocks|website=Bloomberg.com}}</ref>
{{As of|2016}}, Intarcia is engaged in development of a "potential once-a-year [[type 2 diabetes]] treatment". Referred to as ITCA 650, the therapeutic consists of [[exenatide]] delivered via its Medici Drug Delivery System,<ref name=clingov/> "a drug delivery platform that stabilizes and delivers therapeutic proteins and peptides".<ref name=bloombergsnapshot/>
==Investors== In November 2012, Intarcia received $210M in preferred stock and debt financing from, The Baupost Group, [[Farallon Capital Management]], [[New Enterprise Associates]], New Leaf Venture Partners and [[Venrock Associates]]. <ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.techrockies.com/story/0009464.html | date=November 15, 2012 | title=AtTaIntarcia raises $210M as it pushes once-a-year diabetes treatment into Phase III, moves HQ to Boston area | work=BizJournals | accessdate=November 7, 2013}}</ref> Other Investors include Greenspring Associates ,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://greenspringassociates.com/direct-investments | date=November 7, 2013 | title=Direct Investments | work=Greenspring Associates | accessdate=November 7, 2013}}</ref> Alta Partners and Granite Venture Partners.
In April 2014, Intarcia secured an additional $200M in financing. RA Capital led the round and was joined by new and existing investors.<ref name="fiercebiotech.com"/> In April 2015, the company raised $225M in exchange for 1.5% of future global net sales of ITCA 650.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/startup-intarcia-raises-225-million-1430186581|title=Startup Intarcia Raises $225 Million|first=Ron|last=Winslow|date=April 28, 2015|publisher=|via=www.wsj.com}}</ref> In May 2016, Intarcia secured an additional $75M in financing to scale-up manufacturing and inventory in anticipation of ITCA 650s global launch.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fiercebiotech.com/medical-devices/intarcia-raises-75m-touts-final-data-as-it-preps-to-launch-once-yearly-diabetes|title=Intarcia raises $75M, touts final data as it preps to launch once-yearly diabetes drug implant|website=www.fiercebiotech.com}}</ref> In September 2016, Intarcia raised an additional $215M in equity financing to prepare for the commercial launch of ITCA 650 in late 2017 and additional pipeline programs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2016/09/15/diabetes-unicorn-raises-final-vc-round-before-ipo/|title=Diabetes 'Unicorn' Raises Final VC Round Before IPO|website=Fortune}}</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist|2|refs=
<ref name=bloombergsnapshot>{{Citation |title=Company Overview of Intarcia Therapeutics, Inc. |work=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=25608 |accessdate=November 15, 2012 }}</ref>
<ref name=clingov>{{Citation |publication-date=May 1, 2012 |title=Study of ITCA 650 (Exenatide in DUROS) in Subjects With Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus |work=[[ClinicalTrials.gov]] |url=http://www.clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT00943917 |accessdate=November 15, 2012 }}</ref>
<ref name=sec>{{Citation |title=Exhibit 4.1 |publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]] |url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1086688/000104746905022425/a2162566zex-4_1.htm |accessdate=November 15, 2012 }}</ref>
<ref name=leuty>{{Citation |author=Ron Leuty |publication-date=November 15, 2012 |title=Intarcia raises $210M as it pushes once-a-year diabetes treatment into Phase III, moves HQ to Boston area |periodical=[[San Francisco Business Times]] |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/blog/biotech/2012/11/intarcia-diabetes-boston-fundraising.html |accessdate=November 15, 2012 }}</ref>
<ref name=S12005>{{Citation |publication-date=March 18, 2005 |title=INTARCIA THERAPEUTICS, INC. |work=AMENDMENT NO. 1 TO FORM S-1 |edition= |series= |volume= |issue= |publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]] |url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1086688/000104746905007071/a2153238zs-1a.htm |accessdate=November 15, 2012 }}</ref>
}}
==External links== *[http://www.intarcia.com/ Official website]
