revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{notability|Companies|date=December 2009}} {{primary sources|date=December 2009}} }}
'''ViroStatics srl''' is dedicated to develop drugs to overcome the underlying cellular perturbations common to cancer and viral diseases - dysregulation of cellular transcription and uncontrolled cell proliferation. To this end, ViroStatics has focused on selectively targeting the Cyclin Dependent Kinases (CDKs) involved in these perturbations (CDK9 and CDK4/6).
== History == ViroStatics was formed In 2007 as a for-profit spin-off from the '''[http://www.rightinstitute.net Research Institute for Human and Genetic Therapy]''' (RIGHT), a US-based [[501(c)3]] corporation pursuing innovative [[Antiviral drug|antiviral]] therapies and [[vaccine]] research. Led by CEO Franco Lori, MD, PhD, ViroStatics has its corporate headquarters in [[Sassari]] ([[Sardinia]]) Italy, R&D laboratories in the Science and Technology Park of Sardinia (Sardegna Ricerche) in Alghero (Sardinia) and Business Development offices in North America.
== Drugs == ViroStatics has discovered and is developing novel, highly potent inhibitors, which selectively target CDK4/6/9 in a single molecule for a multifaceted approach for the durable treatment of cancers and viral diseases.
The Company has developed a robust pipeline of proprietary compounds, with patent protection beyond 2030, for a number of distinct disease indications.
'''VIRAL DISEASE PROGRAM:''' ''ViroStatics’ unique multifaceted compounds offer the potential for a paradigm shift in the treatment of viral diseases''
*HIV/AIDS: Preclinical Development – Clinical Candidate with Paradigm Shift Potential to Affect the HIV Reservoirs *Other Viruses: Lead Selection for a number of viruses including HPV, HBV and Herpes Viruses
'''ONOCOLOGY PROGRAM:''' ''Designed to Address the Unmet Medical Need for Durable Treatment for Cancers'' * Compounds identified with potential for multiple cancer indications
==External links== *www.virostatics.com [http://www.virostatics.com]
[[Category:Pharmaceutical companies of Italy]] [[Category:Pharmaceutical companies established in 2007]]
{{med-company-stub}}

page.title: Wheelchair Cricketers Welfare Association of Bangladesh

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{notability|org|date=November 2016}}<!-- cited sources are trivial mentions, not in-depth coverage -->
'''Wheelchair Cricket Welfare Association Bangladesh (WCWAB)''' is a national level Non-government and Non profitable voluntary organization established for the development of the [[physically challenged people of Bangladesh]]. The organization was formed by wheelchair cricketer [[Mohammad Mohasin]]. The organization has been working for the disabled people since 2010 aiming to incorporate the persons with disabilities & to strengthen in mainstream society. In 2016, the organization registered under the [[Ministry of Social Welfare (Bangladesh)|Social Welfare Department]] of Govt. people’s republic of [[Bangladesh]]. WCWAB have elected management board. The warriors on the wheel chairs started their journey of playing cricket in 2010. Since then, Bangladeshi Wheelchair cricket players have participated in major tournaments like [[ICRC International Cricket Tournament]] in Bangladesh and Asia Cup in India.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/2016/10/17/49756/First-ever-Wheelchair-Cricket-meet-today | title=First ever Wheelchair Cricket meet today | work=[[The Financial Express (Bangladesh)|The Financial Express]] | date=October 17, 2016 | accessdate=October 14, 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161024022325/http://www.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/2016/10/17/49756/First-ever-Wheelchair-Cricket-meet-today# | archive-date=2016-10-24 | dead-url=yes | df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.thedailynewnation.com/news/111038/khulna-cyclone-emerge-champions-in-wheelchair-cricket|title=Khulna Cyclone emerge champions in Wheelchair Cricket|work=The Daily New Nation|accessdate=20 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/magazine/2016/10/21/cricketers-on-wheels/ | title=Cricketers on wheels | work=[[Dhaka Tribune]] | date=October 21, 2016 | accessdate=October 14, 2017 | author=Afrin, Saudia}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://dailyasianage.com/news/34522/1st-natl-wheel-chair-cricket-tournament-starts|title=1st Nat'l Wheel chair Cricket Tournament starts|work=[[The Asian Age Online, Bangladesh]]|accessdate=20 November 2016}}</ref>
==Wheelchair Cricket Launched in Bangladesh==
First ever wheelchair cricket tournament in Bangladesh launched in 2016 by [[Imago Sports Management]] in association with Wheelchair Cricket Welfare Association Bangladesh.<ref>First ever wheelchair cricket tournament, Prothom Alo, http://en.prothom-alo.com/sports/news/125577/First-ever-Wheelchair-Cricket-on-Tuesday</ref> Thirty Six (36) Wheelchair Cricketers (Twenty Five (25) from outside of Dhaka) participated in this daylong tournament. For most of the wheelchair users this was the very first time they participated in a competitive sports match.

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Use British English|date=March 2017}} Dr '''William Farquharson''' [[FRSE]] [[Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh|PRCSE]] FRCPE FSAS (1760-1823) was a senior Scottish surgeon during the [[Scottish Enlightenment]]. He served as President of the [[Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh]] 1806-8 and President of the Harveian Society in both 1796 and 1805.
==Life==
He was born in [[Balfour, Aberdeenshire]] in 1760 the son of Alexander Farquharson of Balfour (b.1716) and his wife Margaret Davie of Newmill.<ref>http://www.thepeerage.com/p40410.htm#i404093</ref>
In 1790 he was elected a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]]. His proposers were [[James Gregory (physician)|James Gregory]], James Russell and Robert Kerr. <ref>{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp1.pdf}}</ref>
In 1795 he was a Crown Witness at the trial and imprisonment of [[Kinloch baronets|Sir Archibald Gordon Kinloch of Gilmerton]] for the murder of his half-brother Sir Robert Kinloch at Gilmerton House. The trial was judged by [[Robert McQueen, Lord Braxfield|Lord Braxfield]]. Farquharson’s testimony focussed upon Kinloch’s mental state on two previous occasions, each tended by Dr Farquharson (the second being in [[Haddington, East Lothian|Haddington]] jail). As one of the oddest of British judgements, although Kinloch was sentenced to life imprisonment on 15 July, Dr Farquharson offered to hold him securely in his own home rather than in prison, and the judge accepted this on 17 July.<ref>The Trial of Sir Archibald Gordon Kinloch for the Murder of Sir Francis Kinloch his Brother-German, 1795</ref> His house at this time was at Worlds End Close on the Royal Mile.<ref>Edinburgh and Leith Post Office Directory 1795</ref> However, Farquharson disappears from the Post Office Directories for several years; presumably to hold Kinloch in a less urban environment. This was a very considerable personal sacrifice. He rematerialises in Edinburgh following the death of Kinloch in 1800. He then lives at 16 St James Square.<ref>Edinburgh and Leith Post Office Directory 1804</ref>
In 1807 he is noted as donating 5 guineas towards the new Edinburgh Lunatic Asylum.<ref>Scots Magazine and Edinburgh Literary Miscellany, vol70, p.12</ref>
His final Edinburgh address was 2 Elder Street in the [[New Town, Edinburgh|First New Town]].<ref>Edinburgh and Leith Post Office Directory 1822-23</ref>
He died in Edinburgh on 25 January 1823.
==Family==
He was married twice and had two sons: Joseph Canvin Farquharson (who became a banker) and Francis Farquharson of Finzean (1802-1876)
